title: Search for New Solutions to Improve the Efficiency of Solar Cells Using in Saint Petersburg and Hong Kong
reasoning: The abstract explicitly compares thermoplastic polyolefin (TPO) to ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) as a sealant for PV modules in Hong Kong and highlights TPO's outstanding durability and lower degradation rate (0.3% vs. 0.7%). Since EVA contains vinyl acetate, TPO is presented as a safer alternative with better durability and lower degradation, implying improved safety and performance.

reasoning: The abstract compares UV-cured urethane elastomers architected materials to ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and other foamed materials used in medical insoles, noting that EVA deformed in fatigue tests while the urethane elastomer materials showed better fatigue resistance and UV resistance. title: The Effects of Global Damp Heat Ageing on Debonding of Polyolefin Glass Laminates
reasoning: The abstract explicitly states that polyolefin elastomers (POE) have been established as a promising alternative to ethylene vinyl acetate copolymers (EVA), which contain vinyl acetate. These points suggest safety advantages related to environmental degradation and ion migration, supporting POE as a safer alternative to vinyl acetate-containing EVA.

title: How to Avoid Acid Corrosion of Laminated Solar Panels by Replacing the Encapsulant
reasoning: The abstract explicitly identifies ethylene-vinyl acetate (EVA) as the commonly used encapsulant that releases corrosive acetic acid as it ages, creating a need for alternatives. It investigates a polyethylene-based elastomer-type foil, polyolefin elastomer (POE), as a prospective alternative and compares it to EVA from a corrosion perspective, implying a safety advantage related to acid corrosion. This indicates POE is presented as a safer alternative to EVA (which contains vinyl acetate).
